Re: License #: CB820201130
Dear Ms. Stenzel:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
1/30/2023. An Exit Conference was held with the agency on 2/6/2023. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 734-395-0920.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the hosehold shall
have training in aid and maintain a current
certification in first aid from the American Heart
Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
Two of seven open foster home records reviewed showed the respective foster
parent’s ceritificates were not maintained per the rule:
• One foster home’s updated first aid cerificate was due by October 2021
and completed late on 2/13/22.
• A second foster home’s updated first aid certificate was due by July
2021 and completed late on 2/8/2022.
Repeat Violation- Interim December 2020.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
2

(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both of the following shall
be documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care
up to the time of the change in placement and the
needs that remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of five closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
(a) and (b) as required by the rule. The information was left blank on the action
summary.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at
a minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of a
compliance:
• One child’s record did not show documentation of a medical
examination which was due by 11/16/2022.
• A second child’s record showed the child medical examination was due
by 2/11/2022 and completed late on 7/22/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at
a minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age
and older, including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months
before placement or a new dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after
placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
the child’s dental examination which was due by 1/15/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
3

(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster family,
including information about siblings who do not reside
in the foster home.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
(c)-(h) related to the child’s replacement on 1/22/2022 and 4/1/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for
adoption with a signed and dated copy of the
evaluation and recommendation upon its completion.
Two of nine adoptive family evaluations reviewed did not show compliance as
described by the rule.

FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans- Overview, Types, And
Timeframes.
Supervisor Approval:
The supervisor must approve all case service plans

Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as

• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
R400.12327(6)(a) Special evaluation.
• The agency was apprised its letter to the foster family that the special
evaluation report is attached shall not be dated prior to the special
evaluation report's approval date.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12311(4) Foster parent/ agency agreement:
• The agency was advised ensuring that its staff are all utilizing the most
updated agreement may ensure ongoing rule compliance.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of corporal punishment during this licensing period:
The incident related to an allegation that the foster child was getting spanked. During
the investigation the foster parent admitted that they patted the child on the butt. The
agency was found in violation of the behavior management rule, and a corrective
action plan was developed with the family that indicated the foster parents would
complete training discussing the negatives of corporal punishment.
The agency abided by departmental timeframes and standards. They received
technical assistance related to R400.12327(6)(a) as indicated in this report.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s Renewal Inspection whereby
they received the following violations:
7

• MCL 722.120(3) Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports….
• R400.12311(2)(e) Foster parent /agency agreement.
• R400.12324(2) (b) Reevaluation.
• R400.12326(1)(f)(g) Borrowed home.
• R400.12327(5)(d)(e) Special evaluation.
• R400.12418(2)(a) Development of service plans.
• ISEP 6.30 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66)
• ISEP 6.49(a) Medical passports (Commitment 85).
• ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
• FOM 722-6H Documentation of contacts.
• FOM 722-8 Initial service plans.
• FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
• FOM 722-9 Updates service plans.
• SRM 200 Fingerprints.
The agency provided calendar tools, service plans tools and checklists; along with
medical and dental timeframe tools; email reminders to workers by supervisors of
report due dates, DHS-69s tracking, verification of trainings; and adoption quarterly
progress report and case assignment tracking tools it reported it would do, aimed at
completion of its Renewal Inspection corrective action plan. The agency made
progress with this Renewal Inspection corrective action plan but were not totally
successful with all as indicated by the repeat violations indicated in this inspection
report.
The second corrective action plan related to Special investigation 2022C0201017;
which was initiated 5/23/2022. The allegation was that the agency had not submitted
five closed adoption records for permanent retention one year following the final
order of adoption. The agency received a citation for R400.12713(5) for Adoption
placement. The agency reported the five records in question were submitted to the
department on 5/27/2022. Receipt acknowledgement forms showing the records’
submissions were provided during the investigation; and I reviewed those receipts
dated 5/27/2022. The agency’s corrective action plan indicated going forward it
would distribute closed adoption records to the department quarterly. Additionally,
that the director and the agency’s executive administrative assistance would have a
tickler reminder one month prior to when the records are to be mail/sent out. The
CAP was to be completed by 8/1/2022. I reviewed a copy of the agency’s closed
adoption record procedure; and various receipt acknowledgement forms submitted
to various county offices showing timely submission. This CAP has been completed.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency completed an annual Chief Administrator's report as required by the
rule. No obvious concerns were noted.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted an annual budget and financial report, no obvious concerns
were noted.
8

Staff Interviews
Foster care and adoption staff (two foster care workers, one licensing worker, one
adoption worker, also with the indicated administrative staff) were interviewed during
this Interim inspection. No concerns were indicated. The agency does not offer
independent living services whereby any youths would be interviewed.
It is noteworthy the agency has experienced additional growth and has added
another foster care team. It has also expanded its foster care services to include
onsite therapeutic services to the children and families it serves. The agency has
completed a therapeutic brochure and referral process. It has a full-time therapist,
and it has recently started to accept internal referrals.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency did not reveal any areas of concern.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were three safety alerts this inspection:
Safety Alert # 1, received 9/14/2022
Concern:
The home does not have a working smoke detector in the bedroom or hallway where
the children sleep. The caregiver indicated the smoke detector was removed and
would be replaced by the City of Warren. The Department of Child Welfare
Licensing (DCWL) Analyst requested verification the latter was completed.
Resolution:
The agency contacted the relative caregiver on 9/15/2022 to verify that the working
smoke detector was installed and working. The family recorded the smoke alarm
working and submitted it to the agency licensing specialist on 9/15/2022. The
agency provided a photo of the installed detectors.
Safety Alert # 2, received 10/31/2022:
Concern:
There were no working smoke detectors in the home. The relative caregiver was
made aware of the concern and indicated they will get batteries. The DCWL Analyst
requested verification the smoke detectors are working.
Resolution:
The agency’s foster care worker made a home visit to the relative’s house on
11/1/2022 and verified that the smoke detectors were all in working order. The
agency provided photos showing the home’s upstairs and downstairs smoke
detector.
Concern:
There was large amounts of dog feces observed in the relative’s bedroom and
basement.
9

Resolution:
The agency reported that during the foster care worker’s home visit on 11/1/2022 the
worker went downstairs and verified that the dog feces was cleaned up. No odor of
dog urine or fecal matter was reported in the home. The relative caregiver and foster
care worker created a safety plan related to how the relative would check for and
complete regular dog defecation clean up in the basement and anywhere in the
home. The agency provided a photo showing the basement was clean. The worker
noted that the relative caregiver's home had flooded this year which caused the
floor’s discolored and peeling appearance.
Safety Alert # 3, received 10/21/2022
Concern:
The smoke detector on the first and second floor was beeping and the DCWL
Analyst advised the caregiver of the need for a battery. Verification that the batteries
were installed was requested by the DCWL Analyst.
Resolution:
The assigned foster care worker completed a relative home visit on 11/2/2022. The
agency advised the delay in gaining access to the home was due to the relative
being hospitalized. During the stated home visit the relative confirmed that all
detector batteries were replaced and tested the detectors verifying such.
Concern:
The DCWL Analyst was not given access to the home’s basement and requested
pictures of the space; and verification that a smoke detector and carbon monoxide
detector exists in the basement.
Resolution:
During the agency home visit on 11/2/2022 the agency provided the relative with a
combination smoke/carbon monoxide detector. The relative installed the detector in
the basement and the agency provided a photo showing that installed device. The
agency provided photos of the home’s basement, which showed some items lying
about and areas requiring cleaning and additional upkeep. The agency followed up
and addressed those issues with the relative. The agency reported, no one is
sleeping in the basement, and they developed a safety plan with the relative as of
2/3/2023 that indicates the relative caregiver agrees to not allow the children access
to the basement, and to not store the children’s belonging in the basement. A copy of
the safety plan for the basement was provided by the agency.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
